content.raw: Good point. There might also be issues associated with connections to external clients.
content.html: Good point. There might also be issues associated with connections to external clients.

content.raw:
Actually, that's almost exactly what the [world cloning feature](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=clone_simulation&cat=physics) does. It creates a new world and starts a new server. We would just have to change the physics profile and physics engine in the new world.

Simulation cloning doesn't fully work though; the models velocities and plugin states do not persist.
content.html:
Actually, that's almost exactly what the world cloning feature does. It creates a new world and starts a new server. We would just have to change the physics profile and physics engine in the new world.

Simulation cloning doesn't fully work though; the models velocities and plugin states do not persist.

content.raw: I agree with holding off. Switching engines on the fly is non-trivial, especially when one engine may not support all the features of another engine. This topic could be split out into a separate design.
content.html: I agree with holding off. Switching engines on the fly is non-trivial, especially when one engine may not support all the features of another engine. This topic could be split out into a separate design.

content.raw:
One of the goals of this design is to be able to switch physics engines while Gazebo is currently running, which doesn't currently appear to be a feature. There are a few options for implementing this:

1. Create a function in World that constructs, loads and inits a new PhysicsEngine and deletes the old one.
2. Preload a PhysicsEngine object for each physics element in SDF, and create a function in World to switch between the physics engines.

I originally underestimated the amount of infrastructure needed to implement this feature, so I'll hold off on it for a while.
content.html:
One of the goals of this design is to be able to switch physics engines while Gazebo is currently running, which doesn't currently appear to be a feature. There are a few options for implementing this:

  1. Create a function in World that constructs, loads and inits a new PhysicsEngine and deletes the old one.
  2. Preload a PhysicsEngine object for each physics element in SDF, and create a function in World to switch between the physics engines.

I originally underestimated the amount of infrastructure needed to implement this feature, so I'll hold off on it for a while.

content.raw: Sounds good. No version bump, and use the first `<physics>` block that is marked as `default=true` or the first `<physics>` block if nothing is marked as default.
content.html: Sounds good. No version bump, and use the first <physics> block that is marked as default=true or the first <physics> block if nothing is marked as default.

content.raw: True, just looking for the first physics element with `default=true` would be better than requiring a version bump.
content.html: True, just looking for the first physics element with default=true would be better than requiring a version bump.

content.raw:
Yup, it would require a version bump. Not a huge deal, we have conversion scripts for this.

We still need a way to decide what `<physics>` profile to use if a default is not specified. Take the first one?

Taking this back a step, we could also just say that the first `<physics>` element  specified as default is the one that wins.
content.html:
Yup, it would require a version bump. Not a huge deal, we have conversion scripts for this.

We still need a way to decide what <physics> profile to use if a default is not specified. Take the first one?

Taking this back a step, we could also just say that the first <physics> element specified as default is the one that wins.

content.raw: It's a trade-off between elegance of the sdf structure and backwards compatibility. If we keep `<physics>` as a child of `<world>`, I think we can stay at sdf 1.5, but adding `<physics_profiles>` would require a bump to 1.6 with a conversion file.
content.html: It's a trade-off between elegance of the sdf structure and backwards compatibility. If we keep <physics> as a child of <world>, I think we can stay at sdf 1.5, but adding <physics_profiles> would require a bump to 1.6 with a conversion file.

content.raw: How about putting all the physics profiles under a `<phyiscs_profiles>`. This new element can contain a default attribute.
content.html: How about putting all the physics profiles under a <phyiscs_profiles>. This new element can contain a default attribute.

content.raw: Yeah... If I'm not mistaken, it's impossible to handle the inconsistency of multiple default profiles in SDF. I was thinking that `PresetManager` could simply resolve the default profile as the first one it sees and give a warning.
content.html: Yeah... If I'm not mistaken, it's impossible to handle the inconsistency of multiple default profiles in SDF. I was thinking that PresetManager could simply resolve the default profile as the first one it sees and give a warning.

content.raw:
You could easily get an inconsistent state if multiple profiles claimed to be the default profile. If not an attribute of world, could it be a child element called `default_physics` or `physics_default`?

~~~
<world name="...">
  <physics name="preset1"/>
  <physics name="preset2"/>
  <physics_default>preset1</physics_default>
...
</world>
~~~
content.html:
You could easily get an inconsistent state if multiple profiles claimed to be the default profile. If not an attribute of world, could it be a child element called default_physics or physics_default?

<world name="...">
  <physics name="preset1"/>
  <physics name="preset2"/>
  <physics_default>preset1</physics_default>
...
</world>

content.html: 38cba42

content.raw: Sounds good.
content.html: Sounds good.

content.raw: Doing both sounds good to me.
content.html: Doing both sounds good to me.

content.raw:
Right, on different ports. So in this example, would you spin up a bunch of concurrently running gzservers, each with different profiles?

I think passing the profile to gzserver is a good idea, but it could be quite inflexible. Can I implement an argument to gzserver and another option for changing the profile while Gazebo is running (probably a new gz physics option)?
content.html:
Right, on different ports. So in this example, would you spin up a bunch of concurrently running gzservers, each with different profiles?

I think passing the profile to gzserver is a good idea, but it could be quite inflexible. Can I implement an argument to gzserver and another option for changing the profile while Gazebo is running (probably a new gz physics option)?

content.raw: You can run multiple gzservers on the same machine.
content.html: You can run multiple gzservers on the same machine.

content.raw:
Gotcha... `gzserver` starts a new Gazebo master and won't run if there's a server already running, so the script you proposed would have to start and stop Gazebo whenever you wanted to change the profile. This leads to different implementations of the example script that runs through different profiles, one where gzserver runs continuously and one where it gets started and shut down for each profile...

In pseduo-bash scripting that actually looks like python...

```
for all profiles:
  gzserver --pause
  gz physics -profile profile
  gz world --pause
  (wait to run experiment)
  gz world --reset
```

```
for profile in profiles:
  gzserver --profile profile
  (wait for experiment)
  (kill gzserver)
```
content.html:
Gotcha... gzserver starts a new Gazebo master and won't run if there's a server already running, so the script you proposed would have to start and stop Gazebo whenever you wanted to change the profile. This leads to different implementations of the example script that runs through different profiles, one where gzserver runs continuously and one where it gets started and shut down for each profile...

In pseduo-bash scripting that actually looks like python...

for all profiles:
  gzserver --pause
  gz physics -profile profile
  gz world --pause
  (wait to run experiment)
  gz world --reset

for profile in profiles:
  gzserver --profile profile
  (wait for experiment)
  (kill gzserver)

content.raw: I was thinking `gzserver --profile <name>` is needed.
content.html: I was thinking gzserver --profile <name> is needed.

content.raw:
Something like this?

```
gz physics --profile <profile name> # sets the profile
gz physics --set <param name>=<param value>
gz physics --get <param name>
```

edit: I actually wasn't aware of the existing physics command line tools--you can set `iters`, `step-size` and `update-rate`. Generalizing this to setting any physics parameter from the command line seems like a natural extension of this work, though it could get complicated. It seems like at the bare minimum, `gz physics --profile <name>` is needed.
content.html:
Something like this?

gz physics --profile <profile name> # sets the profile
gz physics --set <param name>=<param value>
gz physics --get <param name>

edit: I actually wasn't aware of the existing physics command line tools--you can set iters, step-size and update-rate. Generalizing this to setting any physics parameter from the command line seems like a natural extension of this work, though it could get complicated. It seems like at the bare minimum, gz physics --profile <name> is needed.

content.raw: Alright, physics elements will have a boolean attribute "default" with a default value of false
content.html: Alright, physics elements will have a boolean attribute "default" with a default value of false

content.raw:
There will also be a bit of GUI work, in order to save physics changes.

Can you add in here the ability to specify a profile from the command line? It would be nice to show the ability to run through a wide set of parameters with a simple script.
content.html:
There will also be a bit of GUI work, in order to save physics changes.

Can you add in here the ability to specify a profile from the command line? It would be nice to show the ability to run through a wide set of parameters with a simple script.

content.raw: Starting to encourage leaving out "Get" and "Set" from function names. Could you make that change here?
content.html: Starting to encourage leaving out "Get" and "Set" from function names. Could you make that change here?

content.raw: Thanks.
content.html: Thanks.

content.raw: Attributes should only describe the element to which it is associated. In this case "default_physics" does not describe the world. It would be cleaner to directly attach a `default` attribute to one of the physics profiles.
content.html: Attributes should only describe the element to which it is associated. In this case "default_physics" does not describe the world. It would be cleaner to directly attach a default attribute to one of the physics profiles.

content.raw: It helps fulfill the design described in the milestone 8 report.
content.html: It helps fulfill the design described in the milestone 8 report.

content.raw:
We should add a backwards compatibility test case:

 - Initialize a world with a legacy `<world>` and `<physics>` blocks without `default_physics` or `name` attributes. The world should assign a default name to a profile based on the given physics parameters, and set it as default.
content.html:
We should add a backwards compatibility test case:

  • Initialize a world with a legacy <world> and <physics> blocks without default_physics or name attributes. The world should assign a default name to a profile based on the given physics parameters, and set it as default.
